Headline.Para: John Boyega started company to explore roles he can play, doubled as producer in Pacific Rim: Uprising

LeadPara.Para: The actor started a company to explore the roles he can play and doubled as a producer in the movie, Pacific Rim: Uprising
Much like his character in the last two Star Wars films, British actor John Boyega is not one to sit back and take life as it comes.

TailParas.Para: He makes things happen.

After rocketing to international renown on the back of his series debut in The Force Awakens (2015), he went to work with the most in-demand female director in Hollywood today, shooting the real-life race-riot drama Detroit (2017) with Kathryn Bigelow.

Now, after starring in The Last Jedi (2017), he is back in cinemas as the leading man in Pacific Rim: Uprising, on which he also worked as a producer, sharing the credit with some major Hollywood players, including franchise founder Guillermo del Toro.
The movie is showing in cinemas.
"I founded my company (Upperroom Entertainment Limited) in 2015 and I wanted to collaborate with the best," Boyega, 26, says of his move into producing, at Corinthia Hotel in London.
"As an actor, you run the risk of not having your talents fully explored if you don't have the right roles. People will never know how versatile you can really be."

Hence he sat down with Legendary, the production company that had launched the Pacific Rim series with del Toro back in 2013, setting giant robots against equally giant alien monsters.
"Rather than waiting for someone else to get an idea that happens to be in line with what I want, I thought I should try and create these things myself," says Boyega.
He cites one particular scene in Pacific Rim: Uprising as an example of seeing his creative input come to fruition on screen.

After watching the first cut of the film - in which he stars as a pilot of a Jaeger, a giant robot designed to fight enormous, dinosaur-like extra-terrestrial invaders - he and director Steven DeKnight decided that it was a bit too gloomy.
"We watched it and we both said, 'Why is everyone so serious, angry and down?'" he recalls.
So they arranged two weeks of reshoots and included a lighter scene in which Boyega and co-star Scott Eastwood enjoy back-and-forth banter over the creation of an ice cream sundae.
"Those humorous scenes are the reshoots, stuff that we did later, especially the ice cream sundae. I thought that was something we needed to give the characters a bit more flavour."
Boyega's work as a film-maker, he says, is instinctual. He did not grow up as a devotee of cinema, spending hours studying the craft, even though his parents were both film fans.
"When I was young, I didn't know about film-makers," he says, "and I didn't really care about them."
His path began with theatre.

He enjoyed acting in class plays in primary school and it was during one such production that he was spotted by the artistic director of Theatre Peckham, which encourages youngsters from less privileged areas in south London to explore drama.
"I was doing it because I enjoyed it," he says. "I was spending time with other kids who loved the same thing and who would much rather work on stage than, say, go to a football match."
When adulthood loomed, he began thinking about acting as a viable career.

His parents, who are of Nigerian descent, did not earn huge salaries - his mother worked with the disabled, his father as a Pentecostal minister - and Boyega became aware that they were working hard to support their family. "I knew I had to work and thought that acting had to become my career. I thought, 'If I am going to work towards it, now is the best time.'"
He secured a place studying performing arts at South Thames College before going to train at the Identity School of Acting in East London.
His first break in cinema came when he scooped the role of teen hoodlum leader Moses in 2011's Attack The Block, emerging victorious from an open casting call with 1,500 other kids.

As his film career took off, he was set to star in the Jesse Owens movie, Race (2016), but dropped out when he won the part of Finn, a renegade Stormtrooper, in Star Wars Episode VII: The Force Awakens.
"With the opportunity that Star Wars has given me, I've been able to attract creators on a professional, high-end level. It's been great."
Because of his work on Star Wars, he suddenly had a calling card in Hollywood. "And the production company just felt like another machine to add to my system."
With further opportunities in Star Wars and a storyline designed to create a third Pacific Rim movie, he has a system that looks set to grow.
